Article Title: 'Vallabhjee refused to join camp despite assurances'
Article Text: BENGALURU: Taking objection to India football team 's mental coach Shayamal Vallabhjee airing his grievances in the media, the All India Football Federation on Thursday said despite assurances, the sports psychologist refused to join the national camp in Bhubaneswar ahead of the World Cup qualifiers against Kuwait and Qatar."The AIFF, with inputs and requests from the National coach, was in the process of finalising the agreement with Vallabhjee on mutually agreed terms for services already rendered and those to be rendered in the future. As of date, the terms and release of payment remained subject to the finalisation of the agreement (which Vallabhjee was still negotiating) and the approval of the AIFF Finance Committee and Vallabhjee was fully aware of the same. Despite being assured that the payments would be duly made upon completion of the process, he has refused to join the camp thus far and has also cited certain other commitments that do not enable him to join the team before June 2," AIFF acting secretary-general M Satyanarayan told TOI in an email clarifying the federation's stand on the matter.TOI had reported on Thursday that Vallabhjee was waiting for the federation to clear his dues so that he can join the national camp to help the India team players. "Vallabhjee, in written discussions with former AIFF Secretary General Shaji Prabhakaran , had originally volunteered his services as a sports psychologist/mental coach to the National Team since March 2023 on a pro bono basis. He has agreed that this would remain the case until it was mutually agreed to compensate him for his services. As of date there is no agreement between Vallabhjee and the AIFF under which he is entitled to any payments. Thus the question of amounts legally due to him does not arise," he said.The Federation also condemned the statements made by Vallabhjee. "These are not only an attempt on his part to show the AIFF in poor light but present an incomplete and misleading picture. The AIFF condemns such conduct and shall be conferring internally to determine the appropriate next steps," the email said."We were always willing to accommodate his requests and he waited this long. We had agreed on the future compensation and also for the work he had done in the past. I wonder what stopped him from believing us," Satyanarayan said. When asked about the delay in payment, the AIFF official said. "With no agreement in place, we also had to take the permission of the finance committee."
Article Summary: Shayamal Vallabhjee refused to join the national camp in Bhubaneswar ahead of the World Cup qualifiers against Kuwait and Qatar. The All India Football Federation took objection to the mental coach airing his grievances in the media. AIFF acting secretary-general M Satyanarayan told TOI in an email clarifying the federation's stand on the matter.

Article Title: British Indian joins Pakistan football team as assistant coach
Article Text:
(With inputs from PTI)

NEW DELHI: Trishan Patel , a British Indian, has been appointed as the assistant coach and performance analyst for the Pakistan football team.Trishan has joined the squad in Islamabad, according to the Pakistan Football Federation ( PFF ).Prior to his in-person coaching role, Trishan, who holds a UEFA A-level coaching license, had been providing online coaching to the Pakistan team."He will be assisting head coach Stephen Constantine in preparing the team for the World Cup preliminary qualifying matches in the Asia region," said a PFF official.He added that Trishan would be with the team for the matches against Saudi Arabia and Tajikistan.The home match against Saudi Arabia will be played on June 6 while the away game against Tajikistan is on June 11.The official said that Trishan had a lot of coaching experience, having worked with the Liverpool academy and also with Luton Town FC.
Article Summary: Trishan Patel, a British Indian, has been appointed as the assistant coach and performance analyst for the Pakistan football team. He will be assisting head coach Stephen Constantine in preparing the team for the World Cup preliminary qualifying matches in the Asia region. The home match against Saudi Arabia will be played on June 6.

Article Title: Kerala Blasters appoint Mikael Stahre as head coach
Article Text: KOCHI: Kerala Blasters FC has named Mikael Stahre , a 48-year-old Swedish coach, as their new head coach on a two-year contract that will keep him with the team until 2026. Stahre will replace Ivan Vukomanovic , who departed after three seasons as head coach. The new coach is set to join the team at the beginning of the pre-season.Stahre managed over 400 matches with notable teams across various countries, including Sweden, Greece, China, USA, Norway, and Thailand. His most significant achievements include leading AIK to the Swedish Allsvenskan title, Svenska Cupen, and Supercupen, as well as guiding IFK Göteborg to the Svenska Cupen."After some inspiring & positive discussions with the management, I'm delighted to be joining Kerala Blasters. It is a fantastic privilege. I am very proud to be able to continue my coaching career in Asia, and to explore my third country on this beautiful continent. I look forward to coming to India soon and meeting everyone. Let's do some great things together," said Stahre."Mikael is an excellent candidate, full of hunger and motivation, who ticked all the boxes of what we were looking for in our coach. He possesses immense experience and strong leadership. I'm happy to have Mikael on board and I look forward to working together," said Blasters' sporting director Karolis Skinkys.Stahre's coaching career began with Vasby United before he took charge of AIK in 2008, leading them to a Swedish League Title and Swedish Cup double in 2009. He then had stints with Panionos in Greece, IFK Göteborg in Sweden, Dalian Yifeng in China, BK Hacken in Sweden, San Jose Earthquakes in the USA, Sarpsborg 08 in Norway, and Uthai Thani in Thailand. In addition to his head coaching roles, Stahre has 14 years of experience in youth coaching with Gröndals, Hammarby, and AIK from 1990-2005, during which he led the AIK Under-19 team to a national title in 2004.
Article Summary: Mikael Stahre has been appointed as the new head coach of Kerala Blasters. The 48-year-old Swede will replace Ivan Vukomanovic, who left after three seasons. He has managed over 400 matches across various countries, including Sweden, Greece, China, USA, Norway, and Thailand.

Article Title: Kerala Blasters appoint Mikael Stahre as the club’s new head coach
Article Text:
(Inputs from agencies)

NEW DELHI: Kerala Blasters Football Club announced the appointment of Mikael Stahre as the Club's new head coach on Thursday. The 48-year-old Swedish coach has signed a two-year contract, which will see him lead the team until 2026.Throughout his career, Stahre has managed more than 400 matches with notable teams such as AIK (Sweden), Panionios (Greece), IFK Göteborg (Sweden), Dalian Yifang (China), BK Häcken (Sweden), San Jose Earthquakes (USA), Sarpsborg 08 (Norway), and Uthai Thani (Thailand).His most significant achievements include leading AIK to the Swedish Allsvenskan title, Svenska Cupen, and Supercupen, as well as guiding IFK Göteborg to the Svenska Cupen.Expressing his enthusiasm, Mikael Stahre said: "After some really inspiring & positive discussions with the management, I'm delighted to be joining Kerala Blasters – a fantastic privilege! I am very proud to be able to continue my coaching career in Asia, and to explore my 3rd country on this beautiful continent. I look forward to coming to India soon and meeting everyone. Let's do some great things together. Go Blasters!"Karolis Skinkys , Sporting Director, commented on the appointment, "We followed our process while recruiting the new coach. It was a long marathon of many interviews and discussions to decide who fit the role best. Mikael is an excellent candidate, full of hunger and motivation, who ticked all the boxes of what we were looking for in our coach. He possesses immense experience and strong leadership. I'm happy to have Mikael on board and I look forward to working together."Stahre's coaching journey began with Vasby United before he took charge of AIK in 2008. He led the team to a Swedish League Title and Swedish Cup double in 2009. After a brief stint with Panionos in Greece, he returned to Sweden to coach IFK Göteborg, guiding them to a Swedish Cup in 2014.Stahre's time in China saw him lead Dalian Yifeng to a third-place finish in the Chinese second division. He then coached BK Hacken in Sweden, elevating the team from 10th place to a record top-four finish. Stahre has also had spells in the USA, Norway, and Thailand.In addition to his head coaching roles, Stahre has 14 years of experience in youth coaching with Gröndals, Hammarby, and AIK from 1990-2005. He led the AIK Under-19 team to a national title in 2004.The Club is optimistic that his leadership will inspire the team to perform at their best and compete for titles in the coming seasons. The new coach is expected to join the team at the start of the preseason.
Article Summary: Mikael Stahre has signed a two-year contract with the Kerala Blasters Football Club. The 48-year-old Swedish coach has managed more than 400 matches with notable teams such as AIK (Sweden), Panionios (Greece), IFK Göteborg (Sw Sweden), Dalian Yifang (China) and Uthai Thani (Thailand) The new coach is expected to join the team at the start of the preseason.

Article Title: Premier League club West Ham United hire Julen Lopetegui as new manager
Article Text:
(Inputs from Reuters)

NEW DELHI: Former Spain and Real Madrid manager Julen Lopetegui has been named the new head coach of West Ham United , the Premier League club announced on Thursday.Lopetegui will assume his role at the London club on July 1, succeeding David Moyes , who departed earlier this month. The Hammers concluded the season in ninth place, accumulating 52 points and narrowly missing out on securing a spot in European competitions for the upcoming season.In a statement, the 57-year-old Lopetegui expressed his aspirations as a coach, stating, "My ambition as a coach is always to be better and better, to achieve more and bigger aims and to encourage and improve the players, the team, and to compete because football is about this – to compete."He further emphasized his commitment to the club, adding, "I am where I want to be.I am here because I want to be here and for us it was a fantastic day when we closed our agreement here because our commitment is 100 per cent to be here."Lopetegui's playing career included stints at Barcelona and Real Madrid, although he primarily featured for Logrones and Rayo Vallecano. His coaching journey began within Spain's youth setup before taking on roles at Rayo Vallecano in the Spanish second division and Portuguese side Porto.However, his most notable achievements in club management came during his three-year tenure at Sevilla, where he guided the LaLiga team to victory in the 2020 Europa League.
Article Summary: Julen Lopetegui has been named the new head coach of West Ham United. The 57-year-old will assume his role at the London club on July 1. He succeeds David Moyes, who left the club earlier this month.

Article Title: Ademola Lookman's hat-trick ends Bayer Leverkusen's 51-match unbeaten run, hands Atalanta Europa League title
Article Text:
(Inputs from AFP)

NEW DELHI: Ademola Lookman 's remarkable hat-trick propelled Atalanta to a resounding 3-0 victory over Bayer Leverkusen in the Europa League final on Wednesday, securing only the second major trophy in the Italian club's 117-year history and halting the German champions' impressive 51-game unbeaten run.The Nigerian forward, who had previously struggled to make his mark in the English Premier League with Everton, Fulham, and Leicester City, found new life in Italy under the guidance of Atalanta coach Gian Piero Gasperini . Lookman's goals in the 26th and 15th minutes from fulltime sealed the win for the Bergamo side.Gasperini's two-decade quest for major silverware finally came to an end as his team completely outplayed Xabi Alonso 's formidable Leverkusen side. Atalanta's performance mirrored their impressive displays against Premier League giants Liverpool and three-time finalists Olympique de Marseille in the previous rounds, marking their first European final with a memorable victory.Leverkusen's uncharacteristically sloppy play handed early chances to Atalanta, with Gianluca Scamacca's header from Matteo Ruggeri's cross serving as an early warning. Davide Zappacosta's unchallenged run down the right flank set up Lookman's opener, and the Nigerian doubled the lead 14 minutes later with a stunning right-footed curler from just outside the box.Despite Leverkusen's halftime substitution of defender Josip Stanisic for top scorer Victor Boniface, Atalanta's resolute backline held firm. Lookman completed his hat-trick on the counterattack with a left-footed strike into the top corner, becoming the sixth player to score a hat-trick in a major European final and the first since Jupp Heynckes in 1975.The final whistle sparked wild celebrations among the Atalanta players and fans, as the club ended their 61-year wait for a major trophy since their 1963 Italian Cup triumph.
Article Summary: Ademola Lookman scores a hat-trick as Atalanta beat Bayer Leverkusen 3-0 in Europa League final. Victory is only the second major trophy in the Italian club's 117-year history. Lookman's goals in the 26th and 15th minutes from fulltime sealed the win.

Article Title: Casper Ruud wins third Geneva title to head to Paris on a high
Article Text:
(With AFP inputs)

NEW DELHI: Casper Ruud secured his third Geneva title on Saturday by defeating Tomas Machac , who had previously beaten Novak Djokovic .The Norwegian, currently ranked world number seven, triumphed over the 44th-ranked Czech player with a score of 7-5, 6-3 in a match lasting one hour and 47 minutes.As the second seed, Ruud has found success on the clay courts of Parc des Eaux-Vives, having also won the Geneva title in 2021 and 2022.This victory serves as a significant boost for the 25-year-old ahead of the French Open , where he was the runner-up in the last two editions. Ruud leads the ATP tour in match wins this year, adding another accolade to his impressive season.The 28-man Geneva tournament serves as a warm-up before the French Open, the second of the year's four Grand Slams, which begins on Sunday.It was Ruud's second match of the day, having beaten Italy's in-form Flavio Cobolli 1-6, 6-1, 7-6 (7/4) in a roller coaster semi-final.The contest between Ruud and Cobolli, on a career-high ranking of 56, was meant to take place on Friday evening but was called off due to persistent rain."I'll just take a shower, rest, have some lunch and then start again," Ruud said after his first win of the day.World number one Djokovic took a late wildcard to play in Geneva in a bid to reverse an alarming dip in form ahead of Roland-Garros, where he has won three times.But the 24-time Grand Slam champion was left feeling "worried" about his French Open title defence after falling 6-4, 0-6, 6-1 to Machac in the Geneva semi-finals on Friday.For Czech number two Machac, it was the biggest win of his career and propelled the 23-year-old into his maiden tour-level final, which will shoot him up to a career-high 34 in the world rankings.The last Czech to reach the Geneva final was Tomas Smid in 1987.In the French Open first round, Ruud will face Brazilian qualifier Felipe Meligeni Alves. Machac will face Portuguese number one Nuno Borges.
Article Summary: Casper Ruud beats Tomas Machac 7-5, 6-3 in the final of the Geneva Open. The Norwegian has won the tournament twice before, in 2021 and 2022. Machac had previously beaten world number one Novak Djokovic in the semi-finals.

Article Title: Big, big chance that it’s my last: Rafael Nadal
Article Text:
Rafael Nadal (Reuters Photo)

PARIS: This could be Rafael Nadal ’s last dance at Roland Garros . Then again, maybe not.

“It's a big, big chance that it’s going to be my last Roland Garros,” Nadal said. “But if (you are asking me) that it's 100 percent my last Roland Garros, sorry, I cannot predict what's going to happen.”

“I have been going through a long process of recovery with a very difficult injury, almost two years of suffering, a recovery process that seems like I feel better now,” the 37-year-old said. “I’m not a guy that reacts because I lost there or somewhere else. I react about my personal feelings, and my personal feelings are better now than one month and a half ago.”

“I don't want to close 100 percent the door, because first thing, I’m enjoying playing tennis . Second thing, I’m traveling with the family. They are enjoying. I’m enjoying sharing all this process with them. And third thing, I was not able to explore yet the proper way of how I will be able to play again more or less healthy, playing without limitation.”

Nadal, who will turn 38 in the next few days, asked for time.

“Maybe in a month and a half I say, it's enough, I can't keep going,” he said. “but today, I cannot guarantee that it is going to be the last (Roland Garros).”
Article Summary: Rafael Nadal says it's a big, big chance that it’s going to be my last Roland Garros. “I have been going through a long process of recovery with a very difficult injury, almost two years of suffering, a recovery process that seems like I feel better now,” he said.

Article Title: Rafael Nadal says he is feeling better
Article Text: PARIS: Rafael Nadal was in black-and-white practice gear, he was leaning on the grayscale, but that was all the vintage the 14-time Roland Garros champion sparked on an afternoon when the sun was in the shade.The 37-year-old’s shots were short of signature crackle and his stride was a mite slow.Nadal enters the Paris Grand Slam following an anemic match schedule courtesy a hip injury that kept him off his beloved terre battue last year for the first time after 18 consecutive appearances. The Spaniard played four matches in 2023 and has logged just four tournaments in 2024.Nadal, bidding to finish a storied career on his terms, at the very least end where he started it on the tennis court, will go up against the fourth-ranked German Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday.He’ll need to blast off the blocks. So, where exactly is Rafael Nadal, on a competitive scale?He is ranked outside the top-250 at No 276, but that, in this case, is just a number against a name. Not a measure of the legend.Nadal, who arrived in Roland Garros more than a week before the start of the fortnight, said he’s feeling better than he has in a long time on the tennis court.“This is the first week since I come back that I’m able to run the proper way without having a lot of limitations. That has encouraged me,” said Nadal, who arrived for his pre-championship media interaction in an electric blue tee and a smile to match. “That does not mean that I'm going to play incredible on Monday, no?”The 22-time major winner, who has a glittering 112-3 win-loss record here, retraced his romance at this spectacularly stylish venue.“In some ways this place is magical for me,” he said. “So, if, in the bottom of my heart, I don't have any hope to have success here and to create a beautiful thing this year, I will not be here in front of you guys.”That declaration at once lifted the mood in the packed-to-capacity press room. Nobody wants one of the greatest champions this game has seen, one of the fiercest fighters in all sport, limp into the sunset. That would be a travesty.Nadal, who went down to Hubert Hurkacz in the second round in Rome in his last tournament outing, indicated that he’s able to push more physically.“I don't feel the limitations that I felt in Rome in terms of running,” he said. “I’m not thinking in terms of having amazing results here but thinking about giving myself a little bit more room to think about what can happen in the future.”This then, particularly the last three-four months, has got to be Nadal’s weightiest fight, chasing as he is a wafer-thin chance on the slippery slope of hope. Battling age and wrestling for time.“We did things to try to feel better, and we have been working without a stop to keep progressing, to try to arrive here in a proper way,” he said.Each time Nadal threads the needle with his mélange of heavily spun groundies on a practice court, he’s faced with questions.“I didn't play five-set matches since a long time. I haven’t played this level of opponents since a long time,” he said. “All these questions that you ask me, I’m asking to myself too.”Zverev, more than a decade younger than his opponent, is up to speed having claimed his biggest title in two years ago in Rome last weekThe German is looking to finish a match he couldn’t two years ago when he was wheeled off the court in the middle of their sea-saw semifinal with an ankle injury.“I wanted to play Rafa again, because I didn't want the last memory of me playing against Rafa to be me leaving the court on a wheelchair,’ the 27-year-old said. “For me, in my mind, I'm going to play peak Rafa Nadal. I expect him to be at his absolute best. I expect him to play the best tennis he's played in a long time.”Bring out the popcorn, if only because there's hope yet.
Article Summary: Rafael Nadal says he's feeling better than he has in a long time on the tennis court. The Spaniard played four matches in 2023 and has logged just four tournaments in 2024. Nadal will go up against the fourth-ranked German Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday.

Article Title: Rafael Nadal says 'not 100% certain' it is his final French Open
Article Text:
(With AFP inputs)

NEW DELHI: Rafael Nadal mentioned on Saturday that it is likely he is making his final appearance at the French Open , though he cautioned that it is "not 100% certain"."There is a good chance that it will be my last French Open, but I cannot say that I am 100% certain it will be the last," said the Spaniard.Nadal, a 14-time French Open champion who will turn 38 on June 3, is set to face world number four Alexander Zverev in the first round in Paris on Monday.Since his title-winning debut at 19 in 2005, the Spanish legend has amassed 112 wins in 115 matches at the tournament.With 22 Grand Slam titles - second only to Novak Djokovic 's 24 on the all-time men's list - Nadal's career has been marred by injuries.He has participated in just four tournaments since January of last year due to a hip injury and a subsequent muscle tear.As a result, his ranking has slumped to 276 in the world and comes into the French Open unseeded."I have gone through a long recovery process. Now I'm better than a month ago. So in a way I don't want to close the door 100%," added Nadal."I love tennis, I travel with my family and we are all happy."Nadal had to sit out the 2023 French Open through injury.The year before he won his 14th title but revealed that he could only play with daily pain-killing injections in his feet."Give me a little time and maybe within a month I'll say I'm stopping," he added.Nadal arrives in Paris having yet to make a clay-court quarter-final this season. In Rome, he was defeated in the second round."I feel competitive in training. Maybe not in an official match, but when I enter the court, I feel like I can beat anyone," he said.
Article Summary: Rafael Nadal says it is likely he is making his final appearance at the French Open. The Spaniard is a 14-time French Open champion who will turn 38 on June 3. He is set to face world number four Alexander Zverev in the first round in Paris on Monday.

Article Title: Naomi Osaka hopes dedication to clay pays off at Roland Garros
Article Text: NEW DELHI: Naomi Osaka expressed optimism about her clay court performance ahead of the French Open , as the four-time Grand Slam champion aims for success on tennis ' slowest surface following her return from a 15-month maternity break.The former world number one, Osaka, renowned for her dominance on hard courts due to her powerful baseline game, has historically faced challenges on clay.Currently ranked 134th globally after her extended hiatus, the 26-year-old Japanese athlete is yet to reach a clay court final and has not progressed beyond the third round at Roland Garros .However, she shrugged off early defeats in Rouen and Madrid before a run to the Italian Open fourth round, earning her first two career top-20 wins on clay in Rome by beating Marta Kostyuk and Daria Kasatkina."I think I've made a significant amount of progress and I feel like people can see that throughout the tournaments that I've played, but I feel like I've dedicated a lot of time to learning about clay," Osaka told reporters."I want to do well and I want to keep beating really good players. Hopefully the last stop here I'll play well too."Osaka, who returns to the French Open after a gap of two years, takes on Italian Lucia Bronzetti first up on Sunday."I don't think I've ever played her, not to my knowledge. So I've seen her around and I know that anyone that's playing this tournament is a really tough opponent," Osaka said."Plus it's a first round of a Grand Slam. I'm usually quite nervous during those first-round matches. So I'm just going in there trying my best and seeing if all the lessons that I have learned so far have adapted me into a better player."She will have the welcome distraction of her daughter Shai at during the tournament."Being away from her was really tough, but I called her every day. I saw how well she was doing and saw how happy she was, so that made me happy too," she added."Yesterday she walked for the first time, so I was really happy. We're going to practice some more when I get back. It's really cool to have her here, just to see how much she's grown and how many things she's doing differently. It's surreal."(With inputs from AFP)
Article Summary: Naomi Osaka returns to the French Open after a 15-month maternity break. The four-time Grand Slam champion is yet to reach a clay court final. The 26-year- old takes on Italian Lucia Bronzetti first up on Sunday.

Article Title: Casper Ruud rolls into Geneva Open final
Article Text:
(With AFP inputs)

NEW DELHI: Norway's Casper Ruud will face Tomas Machac , who recently defeated Novak Djokovic , in the Geneva Open final on Saturday. Ruud, the tournament's second seed and ranked seventh in the world, has a strong track record on the Swiss clay courts, having won the Geneva title in both 2021 and 2022.In the semifinals, Ruud overcame a tough challenge from Italy's Flavio Cobolli , securing a victory with scores of 1-6, 6-1, 7-6 (7/4) in a thrilling match at Parc des Eaux-Vives.Cobolli, currently at a career-high ranking of 56, pushed Ruud in a contest that was originally scheduled for Friday evening but was postponed due to persistent rain."It was very, very difficult. I was one point away from losing," said Ruud."I just was able to hang in there and it was a really tough match. I was happy to be able to come back in the third set and pull through."It was a good confidence win for me."I'll just take a shower, rest, have some lunch and then start again," added the 25-year-old.World number one Djokovic is the reigning French Open champion and the Serb admitted he was "worried" about his title defence after falling to 44th-ranked Czech Machac in the Geneva semi-finals on Friday.Djokovic took a late wildcard to play in Geneva in a bid to reverse an alarming dip in form ahead of Roland-Garros, where he has won three times.But the 24-time Grand Slam champion went down to a 6-4, 0-6, 6-1 loss to Machac, competing in his maiden tour-level semi-final.The last Czech to reach the Geneva final was Tomas Smid in 1987.The 28-man Geneva tournament serves as a warm-up before the French Open, the second of the year's four Grand Slams, which begins on Sunday.
Article Summary: Casper Ruud will face Tomas Machac in the Geneva Open final on Saturday. Ruud defeated Flavio Cobolli 1-6, 6-1, 7-6 (7/4) in the semifinals. Novak Djokovic lost to 44th-ranked Czech Machac on Friday. The 28-man Geneva tournament serves as a warm-up before the French Open.

Article Title: 'I'm worried', admits Djokovic as French Open build-up suffers new setback
Article Text:
(With AFP inputs)

NEW DELHI: Novak Djokovic , the reigning world number one, expressed concern over his ability to defend his French Open title after suffering a defeat to the 44th-ranked Czech player, Tomas Machac , in the semi-finals of the Geneva tournament on Friday.Djokovic, who accepted a late wildcard entry into the Swiss clay-court event, experienced a rollercoaster match, succumbing to a 6-4, 0-6, 6-1 loss. This unexpected setback comes amidst Djokovic's efforts to regain form ahead of Roland Garros , where he has claimed the championship three times."Of course I'm worried. I haven't been playing good at all this year," said 37-year-old Djokovic."I've had some good matches here and there but it is what it is. You have to accept it. I don't consider myself a favourite there. I'm going to take it match by match and see how far I can go."Heading into Roland Garros, Djokovic is slated to encounter Frenchman Pierre-Hugues Herbert in the opening round, marking a departure from his usual dominance as he hasn't clinched any titles this year, marking his first such drought since 2018.Djokovic, aiming to secure his inaugural final appearance of the season, faced a medical timeout at the conclusion of the first set, disclosing that he had been grappling with a stomach ailment."It was a terrible feeling with stomach and health today -- it was not a great night and today as well," said Djokovic to atptour.com."But I don't want to take anything away from his win, he deserved it. I don't know what to think about this match to be honest. I want to forget about it and move on to Paris."While in Geneva, Djokovic became only the third man after Jimmy Connors and Roger Federer to rack up 1,100 tour wins.However, even that will not ease the worrying fact that Djokovic is just 14-6 this year with runs to the semi-finals at the Australian Open and Monte Carlo Masters his best performances."It was good that I could come here and play more than one match. I played three," added Djokovic."I just need to feel better. It's not enjoyment when you are suffering on the court feeling this way. You're not able to focus on tennis when you have other stuff happening. I just hope I can be fit and ready and prepared for Roland Garros."Djokovic, bidding for his fourth French Open title, could lose his number one ranking in Paris to Jannik Sinner and must reach the semi-finals to have any chance of keeping the Italian at bay.Machac, competing in his maiden tour-level semi-final, rallied from a break down in the first set on Friday and after failing to win a game in the second powered back in the third set."I'm looking forward to playing in a final for the first time," said Machac who will face two-time champion Casper Ruud or Italian Flavio Cobolli in the title match on Saturday.Their semi-final was suspended later Friday due to rain.On his win over Djokovic, the 23-year-old added: "I have no reaction right now, I just fought for every ball."When you play against Novak you just hope. You just try to play your best and see what it looks like."Ruud, the world number seven, was the runner-up in the last two French Open finals, including a defeat to Djokovic last year.
Article Summary: Novak Djokovic loses 6-4, 0-6, 6-1 to Tomas Machac in the semi-finals of the Geneva tournament. The Serbian is bidding to defend his French Open title at Roland Garros. The 37-year-old has not won a title this year, marking his first drought since 2018.

Article Title: Jannik Sinner not worried about hip ahead of French Open
Article Text:
(With Reuters inputs)

NEW DELHI: Italian tennis player Jannik Sinner has announced that his hip injury has recovered in time for the French Open , though he admits his preparation has been less than ideal.Sinner, who has a chance to become the new world number one in the next two weeks, had withdrawn before his quarter-final match at the Madrid Open and skipped the Rome Masters altogether.The Australian Open champion had previously stated that he would not jeopardize his long-term fitness by playing at Roland Garros unless he was fully recovered. Nonetheless, he is set to participate in the tournament."I mean, I'm not concerned anymore about my hip. The last tests we made, they were very positive. That's why I'm here," the 22-year-old world number two said on Friday."I said I come only here if the hip, it's in a good shape. The general physical shape is not perfect. I didn't play tennis for nearly three weeks, which is quite a lot before a Grand Slam. But look, I'll try to play day by day."This is a little bit different approach of a tournament than it used to be. But hopefully getting through the first round can help me a little bit find my rhythm."Sinner said he has been practising and playing points for the past three days and was feeling "better and better".He will play American Christopher Eubanks in the opening round on Sunday.
Article Summary: Italian tennis player Jannik Sinner has announced that his hip injury has recovered in time for the French Open. Sinner had withdrawn before his quarter- final match at the Madrid Open and skipped the Rome Masters altogether. He will play American Christopher Eubanks in the opening round on Sunday.

Article Title: Alexander Zverev expects to face 'peak Rafa' at French Open
Article Text:
(With AFP inputs)

Alexander Zverev is preparing himself to confront a formidable challenge in the form of "peak Rafael Nadal " at the French Open on Monday. The German, currently ranked fourth in the world, finds himself in a position where he could potentially bring an end to the illustrious Roland Garros career of the 14-time champion.Zverev has been dealt a draw for the first round that many would consider unfavorable, as he gears up to face Nadal, a 22-time Grand Slam title winner, who is set to bid farewell to the tournament after this edition."In my mind, I'm going to play peak Rafa Nadal. That's what I expect him to be. I expect him to be at his absolute best," Zverev told reporters on Friday."I expect him to play the best tennis he's played in a long time on this court."Nadal boasts a commanding 7-3 winning record over the in-form German, with five of their encounters on clay resulting in victories for the Spanish champion.Their last meeting in Paris, two years ago, was marked by unfortunate circumstances as Zverev was forced to retire from their semi-final due to a horrific ankle injury. This injury sidelined him until January the following year, and he has since been in the process of regaining his form.Last week's victory at the Rome Open , where Zverev clinched his first Masters 1000 title since 2021, signifies a significant step forward in his journey back to top form."He's going to finish his career probably before mine," said the 27-year-old Zverev of his Spanish rival who turns 38 on June 3."I really wanted to play him one more time because I didn't want my last memory to be me rolling off in a wheelchair off Court Philippe Chatrier. I really wanted to play him here."He added: "I didn't want to play him in the first round. I wanted to play him in the semi-finals, final, a later stage of the tournament. But at the end of the day, he's not seeded, it is how it is, and I think we're both prepared for a tough battle."
Article Summary: Alexander Zverev is preparing himself to confront a formidable challenge in the form of "peak Rafael Nadal " at the French Open. The German, currently ranked fourth in the world, finds himself in a position where he could potentially bring an end to the illustrious Roland Garros career of the 14-time champion. Nadal boasts a commanding 7-3 winning record over the in-form German.

Article Title: Djokovic loses in Geneva Open semis before French Open title defence
Article Text:
(With AFP inputs)

NEW DELHI: In a stunning upset, the world's top-ranked player, Novak Djokovic , succumbed to the 44th-ranked Czech, Tomas Machac , in the semi-finals of the Geneva tournament on Friday. The match unfolded with scores of 6-4, 0-6, 6-1, leaving spectators in disbelief.At 37, Djokovic opted for a wildcard entry into the Swiss clay-court event, hoping to regain momentum after a concerning slump in form. This unexpected defeat comes just before his title defense at the French Open , where the 24-time Grand Slam champion has previously triumphed on three occasions."I have no reaction right now, I just fought for every ball," said 23-year-old Machac."When you play against Novak you just hope. You just try to play your best and see what it looks like."Djokovic, aiming to secure his inaugural final appearance of the season, found himself in need of a medical timeout at the conclusion of the initial set.As he looks ahead to Roland Garros , the Serb is slated to confront Frenchman Pierre-Hugues Herbert in the opening round, a tournament where he has yet to claim any titles this year.In contrast, Tomas Machac, navigating his way through his first tour-level semi-final, exhibited remarkable resilience. Despite trailing with a break in the first set and failing to notch a single game in the second, he staged a remarkable comeback in the third set to clinch victory."I'm looking forward to playing in a final for the first time," said Machac who will face two-time champion Casper Ruud or Italian Flavio Cobolli in the title match on Saturday.Ruud, the world number seven, was the runner-up in the last two French Open finals, including a defeat to Djokovic last year.
Article Summary: Novak Djokovic loses to Tomas Machac in the semi-finals of the Geneva tournament. The match unfolded with scores of 6-4, 0-6, 6-1, leaving spectators in disbelief. Machac will face Casper Ruud or Flavio Cobolli in the title match on Saturday.

Article Title: Sanskar Saraswat in Indian team for Asian Junior Badminton Championships
Article Text: JAIPUR: Promising teenage shuttler Sanskar Saraswat created history when the Jodhpur youngster became the first Rajasthan player to get selected in the Indian Under-19 badminton team.The 18-year-old Sanskar will represent the junior national squad at the Asian Junior Badminton Championships scheduled to be held in Yogyakarta, Indonesia from June 28 to July 7.The ten-day long prestigious tournament will be organised by the Badminton Asia Confederation under the auspices of Badminton World Federation.Sanskar clinched his place in the Indian U-19 side on the basis of his spectacular performance in the selection trials which was held in New Delhi recently.Sanskar sealed his place in the national team by emerging winners in the four-day trials conducted by the Badminton Association of India ( BAI ).Pairing with Arsh Mohammed of Uttar Pradesh, Sanskar triumphed in the U-19 boys doubles. The duo of Sanskar and Arsh remained unbeaten in the trials and shocked India's top three doubles teams in the round-robin league."Sanskar and Arsh dominated the trials and stunned higher ranked established pairs to emerge as the surprise packet in New Delhi. Sankar created history as he became the first state player to don the national junior squad. A couple of years ago, he was also the first player from the region to get picked in the U-17 Indian team," said Rajasthan Badminton Association secretary KK Sharma on Saturday.The six-feet tall Sanskar has recently shifted to BAI National Centre of Excellence in Guwahati after a three-year stint at the Hyderabad-based Pullela Gopichand Academy."I joined Guwahati centre in March as it has a world-class facility. I was a part of the Indian U-17 team which won the silver in Thailand during the Asian Championship. I will be playing the mixed team championships as well as individuals as we are the No. 1 doubles pair in the team. I hope to win a medal for the country this time too," said Sanskar, who was trained by his father Raj Saraswat early in his career at his Jodhpur-based Drona Sports Academy.Sanskar, who is equally good in the singles, thanked chief national badminton coach Pullela Gopichand for his guidance when he was training in Hyderabad.
Article Summary: Sanskar Saraswat is the first Rajasthan player to get selected in the Indian Under-19 badminton team. The 18-year-old will represent the junior national squad at the Asian Junior Badminton Championships scheduled to be held in Yogyakarta, Indonesia.

Article Title: Malaysia Masters: PV Sindhu enters women's singles finals
Article Text:
(With PTI inputs)

NEW DELHI: The two-time Olympian PV Sindhu advanced to the USD 420,000 Malaysia Masters final on Saturday after defeating Thailand's Busanan Ongbamrungphan in a thrilling comeback match in Kuala Lumpur.In an 88-minute marathon semifinal match, world number 20 Busanan was defeated 13-21, 21-16, 21-12 by fifth seed Sindhu, who hasn't won a trophy in the last two years, as she moved closer to winning the BWF World Tour Super 500 title at the Axiata Arena.Sindhu placed second at the Madrid Spain Masters and won the 2022 Singapore Open the previous year.She had defeated the Indian just once in her career-during the 2019 Hong Kong Open-and this was her eighteenth victory over Busanan.In the summit match, world No. 15 Sindhu-who will be vying for her third Olympic medal at the Paris Games in two months-will take on Wang Zhi Yi of China, the second seed and current world No. 7.Though Sindhu has already defeated the Chinese twice in three meetings, the Chinese nevertheless defeated him at the Arctic Open last year.After appearing unmotivated since recovering from a knee injury early in the season, Sindhu-who won silver and bronze in the previous two Olympic games-appears to have regained her spark as she displayed some aggressivebadminton play this week.It has been a while since Sindhu has defeated big guns such as Carolina Marin, Tai Tzu Ying, Chen Yu Fei and Akane Yamaguchi -- whom she is expected to come across at the Paris Olympics. A title triumph here will provide her a major boost ahead of the Summer Games.Despite her overwhelming record against Busanan, it turned out to be a tough fight for Sindhu as she had to do the catching-up job, with the Thai dominating the proceedings in the opening game It was a physical battle as the two tested each other in some high-quality long rallies. In the opening game, the Thai was spot on with her executions whether it was the leap smashes or superb blocks, drops or precise drives.Busanan kept a good pace in the rallies to open up a 8-6 lead with the Indian making a couple of judgement errors at the backline and spraying into the net.A crisscross net shot, a forehand block gave Busanan a 10-7 lead before she took a two-point cushion at the break.The Thai constructed the rallies well, drawing Sindhu to the net and sending her to the flanks. Soon she led 15-9, which she extended to seven points at 17-10. In the end, Sindhu went to net twice to give seven game points to the Thai, who sealed it with an immaculate backhand block.In the second game, Sindhu lagged 2-4 but clawed back when Busanan found the net. Sindhu sent a stretched backhand into the net and then missed another one at the backline as Busanan led 6-4.A fighting Sindhu, however, managed to grab the lead at 8-7 with a smash and moved to the break with a two-point advantage, following a lethal cross court smash.At 12-10, a long rally ended with Busanan faltering with a cross court net shot. The Thai made some judgement errors but managed to keep breathing down Sindhu's neck at 12-14.Sindhu dished out a trademark cross court followed by another down-the-line return to move to a three-point advantage at 16-13.The Indian dominated another rally, leaving Busanan completely out of position to establish an 18-14 lead. Sindhu soon grabbed five game points and converted in her second attempt.Spectacular in the opening game, Busanan completely lost control in the decider as she was erratic and struggled with her court coverage while Sindhu looked aggressive.The Indian quickly took an early 4-1 lead and increased it to 8-3. Busanan started making too many mistakes as Sindhu seized a commanding 11-5 lead at the half. Busanan attempted to narrow the deficit following the last side change, but mistakes once more marred her play, allowing Sindhu to advance to 17-10.With Busanan missing the net once more, the Indian team secured eight match points. Sindhu raised her arm in a restrained joy.
Article Summary: Two-time Olympian PV Sindhu defeats Thailand's Busanan Ongbamrungphan. Sindhu advances to the USD 420,000 Malaysia Masters final. World No. 15 Sindhu will take on Wang Zhi Yi of China in the summit match.
